content:
Ok I think you need to seriously rethink your strategy. IMAP is NOT going to work for you to do what you are attempting to do.

IMAP is fundamentally different to POP and you need to change your view of mail stored locally to something more akin to a temporary cache rather than a discrete local copy of something that you originally downloaded from a server.

You can still have you local folder and you can still copy and move mail to them, but your IMAP mail account can not form a part of your local folders.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Go to TB menu > Account Settings > Account > Server Settings and disable these options: 

 - Check for new messages at startup 
 - Check for new messages every X minutes 
 - Allow immediate server notification when new messages arrive 
 - under Junk Settings, uncheck 'Enable adaptive junk mail controls for this account'

Note that accessing any folder in the disabled account will cause a connection and message fetch from the server.

If it fails to deactivate:

- check to see if your address book and/or calendar are trying to make connections
creator: siffemoz

creator: Mapenzi

content:
Hello, probably your profile got corrupted. The fact that TB doesn't crash in a new profile tells us that something is wrong in your old profile. It may be very difficult and time-consuming to search and find the culprit, and one needs good knowledge of the profile contents. And if you create a new profile and then copy/paste the contents of the old in the new profile you import also the crash problem. Do you have "crash reports" in Help > Troubleshooting Information > Crash reports ....?

Most times it is easier to restart from scratch, set up your accounts POP or IMAP just as they are in the old profile. Only if POP you must import the account folders from the old profile. Address books can be easily imported, and if you used the Local Folders to store messages you would copy/paste "Local Folders" from the "Mail" folder in the old profile in "Mail" in the new profile folder.
creator: Mapenzi

content: You mention that the message is sent in the copied format. Please clarify. Details will help. From what you wrote, my inference is that the message was sent in your preferred email font. Since the paste was without formatting, it used the thunderbird setting. If you were pasting from a different font, and wanted it preserved, I would expect to paste formatted. Thank you,
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks so much for the reply.

I wish Thunderbird would use the contacts and calendars WITHOUT linking to the Cloud. I try not to have much if anything in the Cloud. If it had an option to select create Thunderbird Calendar or Use Mac Calendar would be great.
creator: in4m8n

content:
You can use Mac "Contacts" in Thunderbird : open System Preferences > Security & Privacy > Privacy > select "Contacts" in the left pane and choose Thunderbird in the right pane. You could export your Mac Calendar(s) as .ics files and import the latter in Thunderbird.

The inconvenience of both methods is that you cannot synchronise calendars und address books between macOS and Thunderbird. As an exemple TB can only read in the "Mac OS X Address Book" but not write, and if you want to add a new address you would have to do it in Mac Contacts!
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Thanks again.

creator: in4m8n

content:
in4m8n said
Adds senders if chosen tot he Mac Contacts app? Superb if so. Same with Calendars?

Unfortunately no ! Read my previous message again since in the meantime I have added one more paragraph at the end :

The inconvenience of both methods is that you cannot synchronise calendars und address books between macOS and Thunderbird. As an exemple TB can only read in the "Mac OS X Address Book" but not write, and if you want to add a new address you would have to do it in Mac Contacts!

That's why I have chosen iCloud. Everything is synchronised between my iMac, my iPhone and Thunderbird
creator: Mapenzi
